docs.snippet: SIR: I have to report that the two schooners brought here by me were captured by us. The first, the Ezilda, was taken on the 30th ult., four or five miles from land, with the Timbalier light bearing W., S., about thirteen miles.

headline.main: OPERATIONS OF THE GULF FLEET. THE PRIZE CAPTURES IN THE GULF REPORT OF COM. ALDEN.; THE AFFAIR AT SHIP ISLAND.

docs.lead_paragraph: SIR: I have to report that the two schooners brought here by me were captured by us. The first, the Ezilda, was taken on the 30th ult., four or five miles from land, with the Timbalier light bearing W., S., about thirteen miles.

docs.snippet: The best method of relieving the poor is a question that comes up every season as regularly as the arrival of cold and frost. Ordinarily we can, most of us, afford to be indifferent to it, so far forth as we are afraid of giving too indiscriminately,...

headline.main: The Relief of the Suffering Poor.

docs.lead_paragraph: The best method of relieving the poor is a question that comes up every season as regularly as the arrival of cold and frost. Ordinarily we can, most of us, afford to be indifferent to it, so far forth as we are afraid of giving too indiscriminately, or of the poor receiving too much.

docs.snippet: The British Mail steamship Karnak, Capt. MESSURIER, from Havana, Oct. 26, and Nassau, Oct. 28, reached here yesterday morning. Nothing of interest had occurred at either port since previous advices. The health of Havana and Nassau is reported as...
docs.lead_paragraph: The British Mail steamship Karnak, Capt. MESSURIER, from Havana, Oct. 26, and Nassau, Oct. 28, reached here yesterday morning. Nothing of interest had occurred at either port since previous advices. The health of Havana and Nassau is reported as good.

headline.main: NEWS FROM THE SOUTH.; STATEMENT OF A PERSON FROM RICHMOND.

docs.lead_paragraph: Amongst the passengers who reached here in the Louisiana from Old Point Comfort was a gentleman named BROMWELL, a merchant doing business in Brooklyn, who, during the few minutes he remained here, having to go North in the first train, gave an interesting account of affairs in Richmond during the the present month. Mr. BROMWELL left that city on ...
